subject: Methane
object: half of n
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: The moles of headspace gas (equimolar mixture of air and methane) can be calculated using ideal gas equation: PV = nRT. GLYPH<0> 1 , T = 303 K, the total number of gas moles (n) in the headspace are 6.64 mmoles, half which accounts for methane. Considering the metabolic stoichiometry of 1 mol of methanol per mol of methane,  the  total  percentage  consumption  of  methane  (or  in  other words methanol yield per mole of methane) is: 2.6/3.32 = 0.783 or 78.3 %.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation is accurately represented in the sentence as it can be inferred from the context that methane makes up half of the total gas moles, given the information about the equimolar mixture and the calculation of the total number of gas moles. However, the sentence does not directly state this relation but rather implies it through calculations and context. The entity boundaries are correctly identified as "methane" is the subject and "half" is the object in the extracted relation.

subject: Methane
object: GHG
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Methane  is  the  smallest  of  the  hydrocarbon  family  in  its  most reduced form, which means it is packed with potential energy. It is also a major greenhouse gas (GHG) which is also called a short-term enforcer, i.e. it persists in the atmosphere for shorter duration, as compared to carbon dioxide (CO2) that can stay in atmosphere for thousand years, but its heating effect is much more potent than that of CO2. Thus, even with a shorter lifespan, methane has 28 -34 times higher global warming potential over a period of 100 years than that of CO2  due to its higher solar  radiation  capturing  efficiency  (Priyadarsini  et  al.,  2020).
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation "Methane is a major greenhouse gas" is directly stated in the source sentence. The subject and object boundaries are correctly identified as "Methane" and "GHG", respectively, which are the entities involved in the relation.

subject: Methanotrophs
object: Natural gas fields
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Major  sources  of  methanotrophs  include  agricultural  rice  fields, natural gas fields, dairy and cattle industries, etc. The difference in the  rate  of  production  and  emission  can  be  explained  by  methane oxidation by the methanotrophs present in the oxic regions of the rice roots  and  rhizospheres  (Conrad  and  Rothfuss,  1991). The  conversion efficiencies  of  transported  methane  by  methanotrophs  remain  in  the range of 70 -95 % in the soil-water interface (Epp and Chanton, 1993; Gilbert  and  Frenzel,  1995). The  rice  field  rhizosphere  community comprises of type I and type II methanotrophs. In fact, no Type I methanotrophs had been isolated from rice rhizosphere, rice roots, bulk soil or floodwater and  only  their  presence  was  confirmed  using  molecular  techniques (Dianou et al., 2012; Pandit et al., 2016; Takeda et al., 2008). Several methanotrophs  with pmoA lineages  from  rice  paddy  cluster  (e.g., RPC1 -3)  have  been  detected  but  remain  uncultured  till  date  (Knief, 2015; Lüke et al., 2014). Methanol production capability of these methanotrophs is yet to be studied. Thus, rice field was chosen for this study since  they  are  a  breaming  source  of  methanotrophs  and  they  are commonly found across India.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The subject "methanotrophs" is explicitly mentioned as a source, and the object "natural gas fields" is listed among the major sources of methanotrophs. However, the relation is only partially supported because the sentence implies that there are multiple sources, not just natural gas fields.

subject: Methanotrophs
object: rice fields
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Major  sources  of  methanotrophs  include  agricultural  rice  fields, natural gas fields, dairy and cattle industries, etc. It is interesting to note that majority of methane (90 %) emitted in the wetland rice fields comes from the vascular transport system within the rice plants instead of ebullition or diffusion through the rhizosphere. The rate at which methane is emitted is much less ( < 20 %) than the actual rate of production in the rice fields. The difference in the  rate  of  production  and  emission  can  be  explained  by  methane oxidation by the methanotrophs present in the oxic regions of the rice roots  and  rhizospheres  (Conrad  and  Rothfuss,  1991). Thus,  they  are present in abundance in rice fields and they act as the main methane sink where they capture around 20 % of methane evolved due to decaying of water-logged  organic  matter  (Rahalkar  et  al.,  2021). The  conversion efficiencies  of  transported  methane  by  methanotrophs  remain  in  the range of 70 -95 % in the soil-water interface (Epp and Chanton, 1993; Gilbert  and  Frenzel,  1995). The  rice  field  rhizosphere  community comprises of type I and type II methanotrophs. In fact, no Type I methanotrophs had been isolated from rice rhizosphere, rice roots, bulk soil or floodwater and  only  their  presence  was  confirmed  using  molecular  techniques (Dianou et al., 2012; Pandit et al., 2016; Takeda et al., 2008). Several methanotrophs  with pmoA lineages  from  rice  paddy  cluster  (e.g., RPC1 -3)  have  been  detected  but  remain  uncultured  till  date  (Knief, 2015; Lüke et al., 2014). Methanol production capability of these methanotrophs is yet to be studied. Thus, rice field was chosen for this study since  they  are  a  breaming  source  of  methanotrophs  and  they  are commonly found across India.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation "Methanotrophs are present in abundance in rice fields" is directly stated in the sentence. The subject and object boundaries are correctly identified as "methanotrophs" and "rice fields", respectively, since these entities are explicitly mentioned in the source text.

subject: Methane
predicate: persists in the atmosphere for shorter duration
object: as compared to carbon dioxide (CO2)
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: Methane  is  the  smallest  of  the  hydrocarbon  family  in  its  most reduced form, which means it is packed with potential energy. It is also a major greenhouse gas (GHG) which is also called a short-term enforcer, i.e. it persists in the atmosphere for shorter duration, as compared to carbon dioxide (CO2) that can stay in atmosphere for thousand years, but its heating effect is much more potent than that of CO2. Thus, even with a shorter lifespan, methane has 28 -34 times higher global warming potential over a period of 100 years than that of CO2  due to its higher solar  radiation  capturing  efficiency  (Priyadarsini  et  al.,  2020).
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation is accurately represented in the sentence, as it directly states that methane persists in the atmosphere for a shorter duration compared to carbon dioxide (CO2). The entity boundaries are correctly identified, with "Methane" as the subject and "carbon dioxide (CO2)" as the object.

subject: Methane
predicate: is the most widely used substrate employed in cultivating this organism
object: M. trichosporium
source_paper: Copy of Adegbola thesis High Density Cultures20251113.pdf
source_text: M. trichosporium is  an  aerobic, obligate methanotroph that can only utilize C1- carbon sources  such  as  methane  and  methanol  as  primary  growth  substrates. It  is  a  Type  II methanotroph  producing  both  soluble  (sMMO)  and  particulate  (pMMO)  forms  of methane  monooxygenase. Methane is the most widely used substrate employed in cultivating this organism.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation "Methane is the most widely used substrate employed in cultivating this organism" is directly stated in the source sentence. The subject and object boundaries are correctly identified as "methane" and "M. trichosporium", respectively, which are the entities mentioned in the relation.

subject: Methane
object: 2.6 moles of methanol
source_paper: Copy of A. Priyadarsini et al. 202320251115.pdf
source_text: The moles of headspace gas (equimolar mixture of air and methane) can be calculated using ideal gas equation: PV = nRT. GLYPH<0> 1 , T = 303 K, the total number of gas moles (n) in the headspace are 6.64 mmoles, half which accounts for methane. Considering the metabolic stoichiometry of 1 mol of methanol per mol of methane,  the  total  percentage  consumption  of  methane  (or  in  other words methanol yield per mole of methane) is: 2.6/3.32 = 0.783 or 78.3 %.
mistral_7b_text_justification: The relation "yields" is not explicitly mentioned in the sentence, but it can be inferred as the context discusses the methanol yield per mole of methane. The subject and object are accurately identified as "Methane" and "2.6 moles of methanol" respectively, since they correspond to the substance that yields and the amount yielded.
